item.title: Trump Pardons Developer Prosecuted by His Administration
item.description: This summer, Trump administration officials had lauded the indictment of Timothy J. Leiweke as an effort to root out corruption and unfair business practices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Lindsey Wasson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Timothy J. Leiweke, a founder and former chief executive of Oak View Group, in Seattle in October 2021.

item.title: Trump Renames Institute of Peace for Himself
item.description: Workers installed the president’s name on the Washington institute, thrusting it back into the spotlight as it is set to host the signing of a peace deal between Rwanda and Congo.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters
item.media:description: The United States Institute of Peace on Wednesday, after President Trump’s name was added to the facade.

item.title: Trump’s Former Campaign Manager Assisted Honduran Presidential Candidate
item.description: Brad Parscale advised the campaign of Nasry Asfura, a right-wing candidate who was endorsed by the U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel, David C. Adams and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Parscale managed President Trump’s 2020 re-election campaign.

item.title: Trump Faces Choices on Russia-Ukraine Talks as Peace Deal Deadline Passes
item.description: The president wanted Moscow and Kyiv to come to terms by Thanksgiving. Negotiations are now stalled, leaving the White House to decide if an agreement is possible anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: “It does take two to tango,” President Trump said after his envoys left a meeting in Moscow with no major breakthroughs in their meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Unpacking Trump’s Immigration Crackdown and Deportation Efforts
item.description: As Trump steps up his crackdown, our reporters explain what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Jess Bidgood
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Border Patrol vehicles near the U.S.-Mexico border in January in Sunland Park, N.M.

item.title: Repatriation Flights With Hundreds of Migrants Arrive in Venezuela
item.description: The flights with Venezuelans who had been living in the United States arrived at a time of airspace safety concerns as the U.S. military pressures Venezuela’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and María Victoria Fermín
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane carrying Venezuelan migrants landing at the Simón Bolívar International Airport in Maiquetía, Venezuela, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Military’s Boat Strikes Planning Takes On New Significance
item.description: The details could raise questions about who was responsible for a follow-up strike on Sept. 2 — the commander who ordered it or the defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: On orders from President Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the U.S. military has attacked 21 boats in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, killing 83 people.

item.title: Republican Anger Erupts at Johnson as Party Frets About Future
item.description: A small group of G.O.P. women have been among the most vocal in raising what their colleagues say is a broader frustration with the speaker.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Pentagon Watchdog Finds Hegseth’s Signal Chat Risked Endangering U.S. Troops
item.description: An inspector general report to be released on Thursday examined the defense secretary’s use of a private messaging app to discuss airstrikes in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison, Megan Mineiro and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s use of the Signal messaging app risked potentially compromising Defense Department information that could have endangered personnel and missions, according to people familiar with the report.

item.title: Trump Returns to Gasoline as Fuel of Choice for Cars, Gutting Biden’s Climate Policy
item.description: The president said he would weaken Biden-era mileage standards, which were designed to increase electric-vehicle sales, calling them a “scam.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Maxine Joselow and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, surrounded by executives from the auto industry, in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: House Republicans Subpoena Jack Smith Over Prosecutions of Trump
item.description: Lawmakers requested a closed-door interview with Mr. Smith, but the president quickly weighed in, calling for public testimony from the former special counsel.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Chris Cameron
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election Case)
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Smith before a news conference announcing the indictment of President Trump in 2023.

item.title: Trump’s NASA Pick Poised to Win Senate Vote After Do-Over Hearing
item.description: The president withdrew Jared Isaacman’s nomination to lead the space agency in June, but senators of both parties appeared willing to give him a second shot at confirmation.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.category: Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Isaacman, the billionaire entrepreneur and NASA administrator nominee, appearing before the Senate on Wednesday.

item.title: What Tennessee Revealed About the G.O.P.’s Trump Trap in the Midterms
item.description: Republican candidates face the problem that President Trump alone gets out the vote that they need. And he alone gets out the vote that Democrats need, too.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Brad J. Vest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters gathered at the election night party for Matt Van Epps ahead of his victory in a special election for the House on Tuesday in Tennessee.

item.title: Bessent Defends Trump’s Use of Tariffs, Says They Are Not Fueling Inflation
item.description: The Treasury secretary said that import levies were not fueling inflation.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent in conversation with Andrew Ross Sorkin at The New York Times DealBook Summit on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Pardons Henry Cuellar, Texas Democrat Indicted on Bribery Charges
item.description: The president used the latest pardon announcement to attack his predecessor, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Henry Cuellar of Texas at the Capitol in 2023.

item.title: Photos of Jeffrey Epstein’s Private Island Released by Democrats
item.description: In publicizing the photos and videos, Democrats in Congress appeared to be intensifying pressure on the Justice Department to release its files on the Epstein case.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Gabriella N. Baez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little St. James, the private island owned by Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: A Progressive Democrat Makes a Long-Shot Senate Bid in Red Kentucky
item.description: Charles Booker is running again for the chamber as Democrats take chances even in heavily Republican states like Kentucky, where Senator Mitch McConnell is retiring.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Timothy D. Easley/Associated Press
item.media:description: Charles Booker enters a crowded Democratic primary field that includes an independent-leaning horse trainer, Dale Romans, as well as Mr. Booker’s 2020 primary opponent, Amy McGrath, a retired Marine fighter pilot.

item.title: Liberal Group to Air Ads Attacking Democrats for Confirming Trump Judges
item.description: The three being targeted are Senators John Fetterman, Maggie Hassan and Angus King, an independent who caucuses with Democrats. None are up for re-election next year.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: New York Times photographs by Eric Lee
item.media:description: Senator Angus King has voted to confirm four of President Trump’s judicial appointees; Senator John Fetterman voted to confirm one; and Senator Maggie Hassan has voted for three, Demand Justice said on Tuesday.

item.title: Fed Pick Puts Pressure on Bessent to Deliver for Trump
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, who is leading the search for the next Federal Reserve chair, could face President Trump’s wrath if the person chosen does not quickly lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: If the next Federal Reserve chair proves to be less than compliant with President Trump’s wishes, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent could take the blame.

item.title: Why Harvard Has Not Reached a Deal with Trump
item.description: President Trump promised a deal last summer. Other universities have agreed to pay millions to settle with the federal government since then, but Harvard, which was asked to pay much more, has not.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Michael C. Bender and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: To end the monthslong fight with the Trump administration, Harvard has signaled a willingness to commit $500 million to work force training programs.

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Open to Letting Street Preacher’s Lawsuit Be Heard
item.description: Arrested after violating an ordinance on demonstrations outside an amphitheater in Brandon, Miss., Gabriel Olivier wants to block future enforcement of the law.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabriel Olivier in Washington, D.C., last month.

item.title: How William Hendrix Became Part of a Racist, Antisemitic Group Chat for Young Republicans
item.description: William Hendrix wanted a life in politics. He found it, with the Young Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise and Georgia Gee
item.media:credit: Chase Castor for The New York Times
item.media:description: William Hendrix, who has not spoken publicly about the group chat until now, said that he was stunned by the intensity of the uproar and the fallout on his life.

item.title: Canada Turns to the World’s Polar Bear Capital to Defend its Arctic
item.description: The tiny town of Churchill has two of Canada’s largest pieces of Arctic infrastructure, but years of neglect have left them in poor shape amid growing superpower rivalry in the region.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tundra outside Churchill, Manitoba, the so-called polar bear capital of the world.
